description: Borrowed from Middle French critique, from Latin criticus, from Ancient Greek κριτικός (kritikós, “of or for judging, able to discern”), from κρίνω (krínō, “I judge”).

entries.meaning: A person who appraises the works of others.
A specialist in judging works of art.
One who criticizes; a person who finds fault.
examples: When an author has many beauties consistent with virtue, piety, and truth, let not little critics exalt themselves, and shower down their ill nature.

entries.meaning: Obsolete form of critique (an act of criticism)
Obsolete form of critique (the art of criticism)

verbs.description: critic (third-person singular simple present critics, present participle criticking, simple past and past participle criticked)

examples: Nay, if you begin to critic once, we shall never have done.
